conclusion: Analyze the circuit both with and without the switch S closed.
The voltmeter measures the voltage across the 20Ω resistor when the switch S is open.
The current through the 20Ω resistor can be calculated using Ohm's Law: I = V/R.
This current also flows through the 10Ω resistor in parallel with the 20Ω resistor.
Calculate total resistance of the parallel combination: R_parallel = 20Ω/3 ≈ 6.67Ω.
The voltage across the parallel combination is V_10Ω = 0.3A × 6.67Ω ≈ 2V.
When the switch S is closed, the 10Ω resistor is short-circuited.
The circuit consists of the 20Ω resistor in series with the internal resistance r and external resistance R.
Total resistance in the circuit is R_total = 20Ω + r + R.
Voltage across the 20Ω resistor can be found using the voltage divider rule.
When S is closed, the voltage across the 20Ω resistor is the terminal voltage of the battery.
Voltage between points a and b when S is closed is approximately the same as when S is open.
The voltage between points a and b when S is closed is 6V.
